summary: This is a federal court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan resolving Ghislaine Maxwell's pretrial motions in her criminal case. The court denies most motions, including those to dismiss based on Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement and statute of limitations, but grants severance of the perjury counts for a separate trial. This document is a court opinion/order (Document 207) filed in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (Case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN). It addresses Maxwell's motions to dismiss the indictment based on statute of limitations, due process (pre-indictment delay), specificity of charges, and legal tenability of perjury counts. The court denies these motions, upholding the applicability of the extended statute of limitations under 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 (as amended by the PROTECT Act) to her alleged offenses and finding no constitutional violation. This is a court opinion and order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (Case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN). The document rules on multiple pretrial motions, denying most of Maxwell's motions to dismiss charges but granting her motion to sever the perjury counts for a separate trial. It also addresses discovery disputes and sets deadlines for further proceedings.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein signs Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, pleading guilty to state charges in exchange for federal immunity for himself and 'potential co-conspirators' for conduct from 2001-2007.

events.title: Grand jury returns indictment against Maxwell
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with facilitating Epstein's sexual abuse of minors from around 1994 to 1997.

events.description: Trial for Ghislaine Maxwell was set to begin on this date, per the document.

events.description: The perjury counts against Maxwell stem from testimony she gave during a civil deposition in this year.

events.title: Enactment of the PROTECT Act
events.description: Congress amended 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 to eliminate the statute of limitations for prosecuting offenses involving the sexual abuse of a minor during the life of the child victim.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition in Civil Case
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in a prior civil defamation case. Her answers in that deposition form the basis for the perjury charges in the criminal indictment.

keyFacts: The court ruled that Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement does NOT bar the prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York, as it only binds the Florida district and does not cover the offenses charged (from 1994-1997).

The court denied Maxwell's motion to dismiss based on the statute of limitations, holding that the PROTECT Act's life-of-the-victim limitations period applies to the Mann Act charges as they 'involve' the sexual abuse of minors.
The court GRANTED Maxwell's motion to sever the perjury counts from the Mann Act counts, ordering that they be tried in a separate trial.

The opinion details the unusual nature of Epstein's NPA, noting a DOJ report found its provision immunizing 'potential co-conspirators' was a 'stark departure from normal practice' and reflected 'poor judgment.'
The court's rulings deal exclusively with the S1 superseding indictment and do not address the newly added sex trafficking charges in the S2 superseding indictment.

The court ruled that the extended statute of limitations under 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 (as amended by the 2003 PROTECT Act) applies to Maxwell's alleged offenses, allowing prosecution during the life of the child victims, even for conduct predating the Act's enactment.

The court rejected Maxwell's due process claim regarding pre-indictment delay, finding she failed to show the government intentionally delayed for an improper purpose or that the delay seriously prejudiced her defense, despite the deaths of potential witnesses like Jeffrey Epstein.

The court upheld the specificity of the indictment's Mann Act charges, finding that approximate timeframes and the omission of victim names were legally sufficient, especially given the nature of child sex abuse cases.

The court denied Maxwell's motion to dismiss the perjury counts, finding the questions in her civil deposition were not 'fundamentally ambiguous' and that a jury could reasonably find her answers were materially false.

The document cites the legal precedent of United States v. Weingarten (865 F.3d 48) extensively, following its interpretation that ยง 3283 applies if the charged offenses factually involve the sexual abuse of a minor.
The court granted Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to sever the perjury counts from the Mann Act counts, ordering separate trials to avoid prejudice and potential disqualification of her counsel.

The court denied Maxwell's motions to dismiss the indictment based on Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, lack of specificity, and legal tenability of the perjury counts.
The court found that trying all counts together would risk disqualifying Maxwell's chosen counsel, as they were involved in the prior civil deposition that is the basis for the perjury charges.

The court denied Maxwell's motions to expedite most pretrial disclosures but ordered the parties to negotiate a schedule for producing materials like Brady/Giglio evidence, Jencks Act material, and witness lists approximately 6-8 weeks before trial.
The return of an S2 superseding indictment by a grand jury in Manhattan mooted Maxwell's challenge to the prior S1 indictment based on the grand jury being drawn from the White Plains Division.
